Take-Home Exercise 1

Take-Home
Code
Author

Kwee Cheng

Published

September 14, 2024

Modified

September 16, 2024

Background

Millions of people have their lives shattered by armed conflict – wars – every year.

Armed conflict has been on the rise since about 2012, after a decline in the 1990s and early 2000s. First came conflicts in Libya, Syria and Yemen, triggered by the 2011 Arab uprisings. Libya’s instability spilled south, helping set off a protracted crisis in the Sahel region. A fresh wave of major combat followed: the 2020 Azerbaijani-Armenian war over the Nagorno-Karabakh enclave, horrific fighting in Ethiopia’s northern Tigray region that began weeks later, the conflict prompted by the Myanmar army’s 2021 power grab and Russia’s 2022 assault on Ukraine. Add to those 2023’s devastation in Sudan and Gaza. Around the globe, more people are dying in fighting, being forced from their homes or in need of life-saving aid than in decades.

Objectives

Geospatial analytics hold tremendous potential to address complex problems facing society. In this study, you are tasked to apply spatial point patterns analysis methods to discover the spatial and spatio-temporal distribution of armed conflict in Myanmar

Dataset

Armed conflict data of Myanmar between 2021-2024 from Armed Conflict Location & Event Data (ACLED)

Geospatial data on Myanmar Information Management Unit, MIMU

Import the Data

Importing the armed conflict data

acled_sf <- st_read("data/ACLED_Myanmar.csv") %>%
  st_as_sf(coords = c(
    "longitude", "latitude"),
    crs=4326) %>%
  st_transform(crs = 32647) %>%
  mutate(event_date = dmy(event_date),quarter = quarter(event_date))
Reading layer `ACLED_Myanmar' from data source 
  `C:\SMU\Y4S1\IS415\IS415\Take-home_Ex\Take-home_Ex01\data\ACLED_Myanmar.csv' 
  using driver `CSV'
Warning: no simple feature geometries present: returning a data.frame or tbl_df

We work split the data into chunks separating them by the different years 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024

We are also adding a column called quarter to determine which quarter the events occurred in

acled_sf_2021 <- acled_sf %>%
  filter(year == 2021)

acled_sf_2022 <- acled_sf %>%
  filter(year == 2022)

acled_sf_2023 <- acled_sf %>%
  filter(year == 2023)

acled_sf_2024 <- acled_sf %>%
  filter(year == 2024)

Importing GIS data

mimu_sf <- st_read(dsn="data/",layer = "mmr_polbnda_adm0_250k_mimu_1")%>% 
  st_transform(crs=32647)

Data Wrangling

Let’s map the geospatial data set for the year 2021 to give us a rough idea

tmap_mode('plot')
tmap mode set to plotting
tm_shape(mimu_sf)+
tm_polygons() +
tm_shape(acled_sf_2021) +
tm_dots(col = "quarter", title = "Quarter")+
tm_facets(by = "quarter") +
tm_layout(title = "Armed Conflicts by Quarter for year 2021")

Concurrently there are a lot points due to the different armed conflicts, let’s focus on a singular event like battles for now

tm_shape(mimu_sf)+
tm_polygons() +
acled_sf_2021 %>%
filter(event_type == "Battles") %>%
tm_shape() +
tm_dots(col = "quarter", title = "Quarter")+
tm_facets(by = "quarter") +
tm_layout(title = "Armed Conflicts for battles by quarter for year 2021")

Notice that all the geospatial layers are within the same map extend. This shows that their referencing system and coordinate values are referred to similar spatial context.

Converting sf data frames to sp’s Spatial* class

acled_2021_Q1 <- acled_sf_2021 %>% filter(quarter == 1) %>% as_Spatial()
acled_2021_Q2 <- acled_sf_2021 %>% filter(quarter == 2) %>% as_Spatial()
acled_2021_Q3 <- acled_sf_2021 %>% filter(quarter == 3) %>% as_Spatial()
acled_2021_Q4 <- acled_sf_2021 %>% filter(quarter == 4) %>% as_Spatial()
acled_2022_Q1 <- acled_sf_2022 %>% filter(quarter == 1) %>% as_Spatial()
acled_2022_Q2 <- acled_sf_2022 %>% filter(quarter == 2) %>% as_Spatial()
acled_2022_Q3 <- acled_sf_2022 %>% filter(quarter == 3) %>% as_Spatial()
acled_2022_Q4 <- acled_sf_2022 %>% filter(quarter == 4) %>% as_Spatial()
acled_2023_Q1 <- acled_sf_2023 %>% filter(quarter == 1) %>% as_Spatial()
acled_2023_Q2 <- acled_sf_2023 %>% filter(quarter == 2) %>% as_Spatial()
acled_2023_Q3 <- acled_sf_2023 %>% filter(quarter == 3) %>% as_Spatial()
acled_2023_Q4 <- acled_sf_2023 %>% filter(quarter == 4) %>% as_Spatial()
acled_2024_Q1 <- acled_sf_2024 %>% filter(quarter == 1) %>% as_Spatial()
acled_2024_Q2 <- acled_sf_2024 %>% filter(quarter == 2) %>% as_Spatial()
mimu <- as_Spatial(mimu_sf)

Converting the Spatial* class into generic sp format

acled_2021_Q1_sp <- as(acled_2021_Q1, "SpatialPoints")
acled_2021_Q2_sp <- as(acled_2021_Q2, "SpatialPoints")
acled_2021_Q3_sp <- as(acled_2021_Q3, "SpatialPoints")
acled_2021_Q4_sp <- as(acled_2021_Q4, "SpatialPoints")
acled_2022_Q1_sp <- as(acled_2022_Q1, "SpatialPoints")
acled_2022_Q2_sp <- as(acled_2022_Q2, "SpatialPoints")
acled_2022_Q3_sp <- as(acled_2022_Q3, "SpatialPoints")
acled_2022_Q4_sp <- as(acled_2022_Q4, "SpatialPoints")
acled_2023_Q1_sp <- as(acled_2023_Q1, "SpatialPoints")
acled_2023_Q2_sp <- as(acled_2023_Q2, "SpatialPoints")
acled_2023_Q3_sp <- as(acled_2023_Q3, "SpatialPoints")
acled_2023_Q4_sp <- as(acled_2023_Q4, "SpatialPoints")
acled_2024_Q1_sp <- as(acled_2024_Q1, "SpatialPoints")
acled_2024_Q2_sp <- as(acled_2024_Q2, "SpatialPoints")
mimu_sp <- as(mimu, "SpatialPolygons")

Converting the generic sp format into spatstat’s ppp format

acled_2021_Q1_ppp <- as(acled_2021_Q1_sp, "ppp")
acled_2021_Q2_ppp <- as(acled_2021_Q2_sp, "ppp")
acled_2021_Q3_ppp <- as(acled_2021_Q3_sp, "ppp")
acled_2021_Q4_ppp <- as(acled_2021_Q4_sp, "ppp")
acled_2022_Q1_ppp <- as(acled_2022_Q1_sp, "ppp")
acled_2022_Q2_ppp <- as(acled_2022_Q2_sp, "ppp")
acled_2022_Q3_ppp <- as(acled_2022_Q3_sp, "ppp")
acled_2022_Q4_ppp <- as(acled_2022_Q4_sp, "ppp")
acled_2023_Q1_ppp <- as(acled_2023_Q1_sp, "ppp")
acled_2023_Q2_ppp <- as(acled_2023_Q2_sp, "ppp")
acled_2023_Q3_ppp <- as(acled_2023_Q3_sp, "ppp")
acled_2023_Q4_ppp <- as(acled_2023_Q4_sp, "ppp")
acled_2024_Q1_ppp <- as(acled_2024_Q1_sp, "ppp")
acled_2024_Q2_ppp <- as(acled_2024_Q2_sp, "ppp")
#acled_2021_Q1_ppp <- acled_sf_2021 %>% filter(quarter == 1) %>% as.ppp()

Creating OWIN object of Myanmar

myanmar_owin <- as.owin(mimu_sf)
acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q1 = acled_2021_Q1_ppp[myanmar_owin]
acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q2 = acled_2021_Q2_ppp[myanmar_owin]
acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q3 = acled_2021_Q3_ppp[myanmar_owin]
acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q4 = acled_2021_Q4_ppp[myanmar_owin]
acledMyanmar_ppp_2022_Q1 = acled_2022_Q1_ppp[myanmar_owin]
acledMyanmar_ppp_2022_Q2 = acled_2022_Q2_ppp[myanmar_owin]
acledMyanmar_ppp_2022_Q3 = acled_2022_Q3_ppp[myanmar_owin]
acledMyanmar_ppp_2022_Q4 = acled_2022_Q4_ppp[myanmar_owin]
acledMyanmar_ppp_2023_Q1 = acled_2023_Q1_ppp[myanmar_owin]
acledMyanmar_ppp_2023_Q2 = acled_2023_Q2_ppp[myanmar_owin]
acledMyanmar_ppp_2023_Q3 = acled_2023_Q3_ppp[myanmar_owin]
acledMyanmar_ppp_2023_Q4 = acled_2023_Q4_ppp[myanmar_owin]
acledMyanmar_ppp_2024_Q1 = acled_2024_Q1_ppp[myanmar_owin]
acledMyanmar_ppp_2024_Q2 = acled_2024_Q2_ppp[myanmar_owin]

Kernel Density Estimation

After all the data wrangling its time to plot the KDE, however certain parts of Myanmar seems to be dark

acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q1.km <- rescale.ppp(acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q1, 1000, "km")
acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q2.km <- rescale.ppp(acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q2, 1000, "km")
acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q3.km <- rescale.ppp(acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q3, 1000, "km")
acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q4.km <- rescale.ppp(acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q4, 1000, "km")
acledMyanmar_ppp_2022_Q1.km <- rescale.ppp(acledMyanmar_ppp_2022_Q1, 1000, "km")
acledMyanmar_ppp_2022_Q2.km <- rescale.ppp(acledMyanmar_ppp_2022_Q2, 1000, "km")
acledMyanmar_ppp_2022_Q3.km <- rescale.ppp(acledMyanmar_ppp_2022_Q3, 1000, "km")
acledMyanmar_ppp_2022_Q4.km <- rescale.ppp(acledMyanmar_ppp_2022_Q4, 1000, "km")
acledMyanmar_ppp_2023_Q1.km <- rescale.ppp(acledMyanmar_ppp_2023_Q1, 1000, "km")
acledMyanmar_ppp_2023_Q2.km <- rescale.ppp(acledMyanmar_ppp_2023_Q2, 1000, "km")
acledMyanmar_ppp_2023_Q3.km <- rescale.ppp(acledMyanmar_ppp_2023_Q3, 1000, "km")
acledMyanmar_ppp_2023_Q4.km <- rescale.ppp(acledMyanmar_ppp_2023_Q4, 1000, "km")
acledMyanmar_ppp_2024_Q1.km <- rescale.ppp(acledMyanmar_ppp_2024_Q1, 1000, "km")
acledMyanmar_ppp_2024_Q2.km <- rescale.ppp(acledMyanmar_ppp_2024_Q2, 1000, "km")
plot(density(acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q1.km, 
             sigma=bw.diggle, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"), 
     main="Gaussian")

The KDE gave me dark spots so I tried experimenting with different sigma values considering how big Myanmar is

plot(density(acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q1.km, 
             sigma=10, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"), 
     main="Gaussian")
plot(density(acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q1.km, 
             sigma=20, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"), 
     main="Gaussian")
plot(density(acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q1.km, 
             sigma=30, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"), 
     main="Gaussian")

Ultimately settled for a value of 25

plot(density(acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q1.km, 
             sigma=25, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"), 
     main="Gaussian")
par(mfrow=c(4,4))
plot(density(acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q1.km, 
             sigma=25, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"), 
     main="2021 Q1")
plot(density(acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q2.km, 
             sigma=25, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"), 
     main="2021 Q2")
plot(density(acledMyanmar_ppp_2021_Q3.km, 
             sigma=25, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"), 
     main="2021 Q3")

             sigma=25, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"), 
     main="2021 Q4")

             sigma=25,

             sigma=25, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"), 
     main="2024 Q1")
plot(density(acledMyanmar_ppp_2024_Q2.km, 
             sigma=25, 
             edge=TRUE, 
             kernel="gaussian"), 
     main="2024 Q2")
